The closest relatives of this species belong to the whole group of endemic
Monomorium Monomorium from the Canary Islands, which have differentiated into a minimum of five species (unpublished observations). Specific differences are best appreciated in the apterous queen caste, in the density and length of pilosity, shape of mesosoma, petiole and postpetiole, and biometry. In the apterous queens of the species from the Canary Islands a cline can be established in which the more dense the pilosity, the shorter is, and the more advanced are queens in the stage towards an ergatoid condition. Variation in pilosity is best appreciated in head profile, petiole and postpetiole in dorsal view. The most modified species is
Monomorium hesperium M. hesperium Emery , in which queens are the smallest among the group in the Canary Islands and are next to completely smooth and shining and hairs are very long and comparatively sparse.
Monomorium medinae M. medinae Forel , instead, is the most densely pilose but hairs are very short and head sculpture is more developed, as is also in the mesopleurae.
Monomorium wilsoni M. wilsoni is intermediate in pilosity density and length. The head is wider than in
Monomorium medinae M. medinae or
Monomorium hesperium M. hesperium . The mesosomal profile, especially the propodeum, the development of scutum and scutellum (side view) and the form of the strange petiole and postpetiole are also characteristic for each species. This peculiar modified thoracic structure is known in other
Monomorium Monomorium species and has been related to nest founding by budding (Bolton, 1986
